instruction: Marinate the pork: In a large pot, combine the pork belly, water to cover, chopped green onions, smashed garlic, sliced ginger, soy sauce, mirin, sake, brown sugar, and honey. Bring to a simmer over medium heat. Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 1-1.5 hours, or until the pork is tender and flavorful. Let the pork cool in the marinade for at least 30 minutes before slicing thinly.

Make the dashi: In a large pot, combine the chicken broth, soaked shiitake mushrooms (reserve soaking liquid), kombu seaweed, and additional water. Bring to a simmer over medium heat. Simmer for 30 minutes, then remove and discard the kombu seaweed. Strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve to remove the shiitake mushrooms and any solids.
Optional bonito flakes: If using, add the bonito flakes to the strained broth and let them steep for 5 minutes. Then, strain the broth again to remove the bonito flakes.
Season the broth: Season the broth with sea salt to taste. Start with 1/2 tablespoon and adjust gradually until you reach the desired level of salinity.
Cook the ramen noodles according to package instructions. Drain and rinse briefly with hot water.
Heat the broth: Bring the seasoned shio tare broth back to a simmer over medium heat.
Assemble the bowls: Divide the cooked ramen noodles between two serving bowls. Top each bowl with sliced chashu pork (if using), ajitsuke tamago halves (if using), and a sheet of nori seaweed.
Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and toppings.
Garnish (optional): Garnish with sliced green onions, bamboo shoots, corn, a drizzle of sesame oil, or your favorite ramen toppings.
Serve: Enjoy your shio ramen hot and flavorful!
Chashu pork is a delicious marinated pork belly topping for ramen. You can skip this step if you prefer a simpler ramen or use pre-made chashu pork.
Shiitake mushrooms and kombu seaweed add depth of flavor to the broth. You can substitute with pre-made dashi powder if unavailable.
Bonito flakes add a subtle umami flavor to the broth, but they are optional.
Adjust the amount of sea salt to your taste preference for a saltier or lighter shio ramen.
